fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A natural isomorphism is an isomorphism in a functor category. Explicitly, it is a natural transformation whose components are each isomorphisms.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

fr:title.text: The universal property of the standard simplex

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The universal property of the standard simplex

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By the Yoneda lemma, there is a natural isomorphism \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta ^n, X)\cong X_n, where \Delta ^n is the standard n-simplex and X is any simplicial set. In other words, the n-simplices of X are exactly the simplex maps from \Delta ^n to X.

fr:title.text: Equational theory of bicartesian closed categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equational theory of bicartesian closed categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In addition to those of a cartesian closed category and the duals to those of a cartesian category, a bicartesian closed category C saitsfies the following equations up to natural isomorphism:

fr:ul.fr:li: x\times (y+z)\cong x\times y + x\times z (and in particular, C is a distributive category);
x^{y+z}\cong x^y\times x^z;
x\times 0 \cong 0;
x^0 \cong 1.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: To show the first, note that \times is a left adjoint and left adjoints preserve colimits.

To show the second, note that \begin {aligned} C(-, x^{y+z}) &\cong C(-\times (y+z), x) \\ &\cong C(y+z, x^-) \\ &\cong C(y, x^-)\times C(z, x^-) \\ &\cong C(-\times y, x)\times C(-\times z, x) \\ &\cong C(-, x^{y})\times C(-, x^{z}) \\ &\cong C(-, x^y\times x^z). \end {aligned} In particular, the third line uses the representability of colimits, while the last uses that of limits. Now the result follows by the Yoneda lemma.

To see the third, we can again argue by left adjoint preserve colimits. More directly, we argue from initiality of 0 that C(x\times 0, -) \cong C(0, -^x) \cong *. Now we obtain the result by applying the fact that the the Yoneda reflects limits in C^\text {op}.
To see the fourth, note that C(-, x^0) \cong C(-\times 0, x) \cong C(0, x)\cong *.

fr:title.text: Equational theory of cartesian closed categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equational theory of cartesian closed categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In addition to those of a cartesian category, a cartesian closed category C saitsfies the following equations up to natural isomorphism:

fr:ul.fr:li: 1^x \cong 1;
x^1 \cong x;
(y\times z)^x\cong y^x\times z^x;
x^{y\times z}\cong (x^y)^z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: To see the first, note that C(-, 1^x)\cong C(-\times x, 1)\cong *, and the Yoneda embedding reflects limits, so that 1^x is terminal in C. for a more abstract proof, observe that (-)^x has a right adjoint, so preserves limits.
To see the second, note that C(-, x^1)\cong C(-\times 1, x)\cong C(-, x), and representable isomorphism is isomorphism.

To see the third, note that \begin {aligned} C(-, (y\times z)^x) &\cong C(-\times x, y\times z) \\ &\cong C(-\times x, y)\times C(-\times x, z) \\ &\cong C(-, y^x)\times C(-, z^x) \\ &\cong C(-, y^x\times z^x). \end {aligned} In particular, the second step uses the representability of limits.

To see the fourth, note that \begin {aligned} C(-, x^{y\times z}) &\cong C(-, x^{z\times y}) \\ &\cong C(-\times (z\times y), x) \\ &\cong C((-\times z)\times y, x) \\ &\cong C(-\times z, x^y) \\ &\cong C(-, (x^y)^z). \end {aligned}

fr:title.text: Pointwise Kan extensions along fully faithful functors are isomorphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pointwise Kan extensions along fully faithful functors are isomorphisms

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The unit of the pointwise Kan extension of a functor F along a fully faithful functor K is an isomorphism.

fr:title.text: The category of presheaves is the free cocompletion

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The category of presheaves is the free cocompletion

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since every presheaf is a colimit of representables, hence a colimit of objects in the image of the Yoneda embedding, and the functor \hat {F} must preserve colimits, there is (up to isomorphism) only one candidate fomula: given a presheaf P, we must have \begin {aligned} \hat {F}P &= \hat {F}(\operatorname *{colim}(\text {el}(P)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xhookrightarrow {y} \hat {C})) \\\\ &= \operatorname *{colim} (\text {el}(P)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xhookrightarrow {y} \hat {C}\xrightarrow {\hat {F}} E) \\\\ &= \operatorname *{colim} (\text {el}(P) \xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xrightarrow {F} E). \end {aligned} By functoriality of colimits, this is well-defined.

By the proof of the density formula, we recognize this as the colimit formula for the Kan extension of F along y. (Indeed, since the Yoneda embedding is fully faithful, this Kan extension is necessarily an isomorphism, so that this extension necessarily makes the triangle commute.)

fr:title.text: Subobject classifiers are equivalently representations of the subobject functor

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobject classifiers are equivalently representations of the subobject functor

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C be finitely complete and locally small. Then C has a subobject classifier if and only if the subobject functor is representable.

First, suppose *\xrightarrow {\top }\Omega is a subobject classifier. We claim that \Omega represents \operatorname {Sub}_C. Indeed, the assignment (s\hookrightarrow x)\xmapsto {\chi } x\xrightarrow {\chi _s} \Omega of a subobject to its characteristic map is a natural bijection \operatorname {Sub}(x)\to C(x, \Omega ). To demonstrate bijectivity, note that pulling back \top along a map x\xrightarrow {\chi _0} \Omega yields a subobject of x with characteristic map \chi _0; this assignment is unique by uniqueness of pullbacks.

A closed monoidal category is a symmetric monoidal category C such that the bifunctor \otimes is closed. Explicitly, this means there is a bifunctor C^\text {op}\times C\xrightarrow {[-, -]} C, called the internal hom, together with a natural isormorphism C(x\otimes y, z)\cong C(x, [y, z]), called currying.
The counit of the adjunction (-\otimes y)\dashv [y, -] is called evaluation: it is a natural transformation [y, x]\otimes y\xrightarrow {\operatorname {ev}} x.

Applying the adjunction with x the monoidal unit I implies that maps y\to z are in natural bijection with maps I\to [y, z]. By the philosophy of generalized elements, this explains the name internal hom: its elements are maps.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: To show the adjunction, note that we have natural isomorphisms C_T(F_Tx, y)\cong C(x, Ty)\cong C(x, U_Ty), where the first is the definition of a Kleisli morphism and the second is the definition of U_T on objects.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We prove the result for limits and conclude for colimits by duality. For any diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C, the definition of \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D) is the set of natural transformations c\to D, which by definition is the set of cones \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c). A right adjoint \operatorname *{lim}_J to this functor is thus characterized by the natural isomorphism \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c)\cong C(c, \operatorname *{lim}_J D), which is the definition of the limit. Thus pointwise the right adjoint and the limit agree, and so the right adjoint extends uniquely to the limit functor.

fr:title.text: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Right adjoints preserve limits. Dually, left adjoints preserve colimits.

Letting \Delta be the constant diagram functor, we have the following series of natural isomorphisms: \begin {aligned} C^J(\Delta c, GK) &\cong D^J(F\Delta c, K) &&\text {by (1)}\\\\ &\cong D^J(\Delta Fc, K) &&\text {by (2)}\\\\ &\cong D(Fc, \operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the definition of limits}\\\\ &\cong C(c, G\operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the adjunction}. \end {aligned} By definition of limits, this exhibits G\operatorname *{lim}_J K as a limit of GK.

fr:title.text: Right adjoints are initial in a comma category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints are initial in a comma category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A functor D\xrightarrow {G} C is a right adjoint if and only if, for each c\in C, the comma category c\downarrow G has an initial object. Dually, C\xrightarrow {F} D is a left adjoint if and only if, for each d\in D, the comma category F\downarrow d has a terminal object. (Here, c is the constant functor at c.)
In the forwards direction, we obtain the result since adjoint assignments are universal and universal elements are initial in exactly the specified category of elements.

In the backwards direction, let c\xrightarrow {\eta _c} Gd_0 be initial in c\downarrow G; let Fc = d_0. Initiality of \eta _c means that, for any map c\to Gd, there is a unique map Fc\to d in D making the triangle commute. In other words, \eta _c determines a bijection C(c, Gd)\cong D(Fc, d). Moreover, this bijection is natural in D, since it comes from the natural isomorphism which defines the colimit \eta _c. Thus, this data extends to an adjunction.
An adjoint equivalence is an adjunction whose unit and counit are isomorphisms; equivalently, it is an equivalence of categories whose structure isomorphisms satisfy the triangle identities.

fr:title.text: Equivalences of categories promote to adjoint equivalences

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalences of categories promote to adjoint equivalences

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F: C\leftrightarrows D G be an equivalence of categories with structure maps \eta : 1_C\cong GF and \mu : FG\cong 1_D Then there exists a map \epsilon : FG\cong 1_D so that \eta and \epsilon satisfy the triangle identities, hence witness an adjoint equivalence F\dashv G.
There is nothing special about the counit: we could instead choose a new unit to obtain the same result.

Define \gamma = G\xrightarrow {\eta G} GFG\xrightarrow {G\mu } G, which is an isomorphism because all the components are. Then define \epsilon = FG\xrightarrow {F\gamma ^{-1}} FG\xrightarrow {\mu } 1_D = FG\xrightarrow {FG\mu ^{-1}} FGFG\xrightarrow {F\eta ^{-1}G} FG\xrightarrow {\mu } 1_D, which is again an isomorphism. We need to check the triangle identities.

fr:title.text: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F and F' be left adjoints to G. Then there is a unique natural isomorphism \theta : F\cong F' commuting with the units and counits of the adjunctions.
Dually, right adjoints are also unique up to unique isomorphism commuting with the units and counits.
To show uniqueness, note that \theta _c is uniquely specified as the transpose of \eta '_c across the adjunction F\dashv G, but this relationship is required for commutativity with the units to hold.

A two-variable adjunction consists of three bifunctors {C\times D\xrightarrow {F} E}, C^\text {op}\times E\xrightarrow {G} D, D^\text {op}\times E\xrightarrow {H} C and a natural isomorphism E(F(c, d), e)\cong D(d, G(c, e))\cong C(c, H(d, e)). The functor F is called biclosed, while the functors G and H are called left and right closures, respectively.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor so that, for each object d\in D, there exists a cofree object Gd\in C, i.e. an object Gd\in C together with an isomorphism {D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd)} natural in D. Then there exists a unique extension of this assignment into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C, which is then necessarily right adjoint to F.
Dually, suppose that for each d\in D, there exists a free object Fd\in C. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C which is necessarily left adjoint to F.
Let F: C\leftrightarrows D: G be a pair of opposing functors. Then the following are equivalent specifications of an adjunction:

fr:ul.fr:li: there exists a natural bijection D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd);
there exists a pair of natural transformations 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF and FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D satisfying the triangle identities;

there exists a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D so that the formula for adjoint maps induces an isomorphism (-)^\sharp = C(c, Gd)\xrightarrow {F} D(Fc, FGd)\xrightarrow {(\epsilon _d)_*} D(Fc, d).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first implies the second via the triangle identities of the unit and counit.

fr:title.text: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the forwards direction, suppose that the isomorphisms are natural, and further that the left-hand square commutes; the case in which the right-hand square commutes is similar. By the naturality of the isomorphism in C, the transpose of kf^\sharp is (Gk) f^\flat , while by naturality in D, the transpose of (Fh)g^\sharp is hg^\flat . Since the maps are equal, their transposes must also be equal; this is commutativity of the square on the right.

A pair of contravariant functors C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} D and D^\text {op}\xrightarrow {G} C are mutually left adjoint if there exists a natural isomorphism D(Fc, d)\cong C(Gd, c), and mutually right adjoint if there exists a natural isomorphism D(d, Fc)\cong C(c, Gd).

An adjunction F\dashv G consists of a pair of opposing functors F: C\leftrightarrows D: G and a natural isomorphism D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd), called transposition. We say F is left adjoint to G and G is right adjoint to F, and write

When an adjunction is fixed, two maps f\in C and g\in D are adjoint or transposes if they are connected by the adjunction. We sometimes write Fc\xrightarrow {f^\sharp } d and c\xrightarrow {f^\flat } Gd for a pair of adjoint maps.
A cartesian category C satisfies the following equations up to natural isomorphism:

fr:ul.fr:li: x\times y\cong y\times x;
x\times (y\times z)\cong (x\times y)\times z;
x\times 1\cong x.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By the representability of limits, each of these follows from the corresponding result in Set.
Let J\xrightarrow {F,G} C be naturally isomorphic diagrams. Then if their limits exist, they are isomorphic.
Taking limits is functorial and functors preserve isomorphism.

Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in a locally small category C whose limit exists. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(x, \operatorname *{lim} F)\cong \operatorname *{lim} C(x, F-), where the latter is a limit in Set.
Dually, let the colimit of F exist. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} F, x)\cong \operatorname *{lim}_{J^\text {op}} C(F-, x).
A colimit of a diagram is a universal cocone.

By the definition of universal elements, a colimit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{colim} D\in C and a cocone D \xrightarrow {\lambda } \operatorname *{colim} D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} D, -)\cong \operatorname *{Cocone}_D.
A limit of a diagram is a universal cone.

By the definition of universal elements, a limit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{lim} D\in C and a cone \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(-, \operatorname *{lim} D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D.

fr:title.text: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (covariant) functor C\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements \text {el}(F) has a initial object. Dually, a presheaf C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements has a terminal object.

First let c\in C represent F, so that there is a natural isomorphism C(c, -)\overset {\alpha }{\cong } F. Then the pair (c, \alpha _c(1_c)) is initial in \text {el}(F). Indeed, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), the bijection \alpha _d determines a unique element f\in C(c, d) so that Ff(\alpha _c(1_c)) = y; this exactly expresses initiality.

Conversely, let (c, x) be initial in \text {el}(F). By the Yoneda lemma, the element x\in Fc determines a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\Phi (x)} F; we need to show this is an isomorphism. Initiality of (c, x) asserts that, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), there is a unique map c\xrightarrow {f_y} d such that Ff_y(x) = y. Now in the proof of the Yoneda lemma, \Phi (x) was constructed so that F(\Phi (x)_d)(f) = Ff(x), so the assignment (d, y)\mapsto f_y inverts \Phi (x)_d.

A (covariant) functor C\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if there exists an object c\in C and a natural isomorphism C(c, -)\cong F to the covariant hom-functor. A representation of F is a choice of such data.
Dually, a contravariant functor C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if there exists an object c\in C and a natural isomorphism C(-, c)\cong F to the contravariant hom-functor.
Let x and y be objects in a category C. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ul.fr:li: x and y are isomorphic;
the covariant hom-functors C(x, -) and C(y, -) are naturally isomorphic;
the contravariant hom-functors C(-, x) and C(-, y) are naturally isomorphic.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Furthermore, by the Yoneda embedding, a choice of any such isomorphism canonically determines a choice of each of the others.
This is immediate from the Yoneda lemma, since fully faithful functors create isomorphism.
We prove the covariant case. The forwards result comes from functoriality of the Yoneda embedding and the fact that functors preserve isomorphism.

In the backward direction, let \eta : C(x, -)\to C(y, -) be a natural isomorphism. Define t = \eta _x(1_x), which is a morphism y\to x, and u = \eta _y^{-1}(1_y), which is a morphism x\to y. We claim these are inverses.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and let c\in C be an object. By the Yoneda lemma, a choice of x\in Fc corresponds to a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\alpha _x} F. Such a choice expresses a universal property of c if \alpha _x is an isomorphism, and hence a representation. In this case, x is called a universal element.
The analogous dual definition applies to presheaves.

Let c and d be objects in a category C, and suppose that F and x express universal properties of both c and d. Then there is a canonical isomorphism c\cong d; in particular, a unique isomorphism that commutes with the corresponding representations.
We are thus justified in referring to "the universal object with an x."

Let C(c, -)\overset {\alpha _x}{\cong } F and C(d, -)\overset {\beta _x}{\cong } F be the corresponding natural isomorphisms given by definition of a universal property. Then their composition gives an isomorphism C(c, -)\cong C(d, -), which lifts to an isomorphism c\cong d by the Yoneda lemma.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set be a presheaf and A\in C an object. Let y be the Yoneda embedding and \hat {C} be the presheaf category. Then \hat {C}(yA, F)\cong FA, and this bijection is natural in F and A. Furthermore, the image of a natural transformation yA\xrightarrow {\alpha } F under this bijection is \alpha _A(1_A).
Dually, let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and A\in C an object. Then \operatorname {Hom}(C(A, -), F)\cong FA.
We prove the contravariant (presheaf) case. The proof is in three parts: the bijection, and the two naturality claims.

A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is an equivalence of categories if there exists a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C together with natural isomorphisms FG\cong 1_D and GF\cong 1_C. Two categories are equivalent if there exists an equivalence of categories between them, in which case we write C\simeq D .
An adjunction F \dashv G between categories C and D entails the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a pair of functors F:C\leftrightarrows D:G, called the left and right adjoints;
a family of natural bijections D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd), called transposition;
a natural transformation 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF, called the unit;
a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D, called the counit.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data relates as follows:

fr:ul.fr:li: the component c\xrightarrow {\eta _c}GFc of the unit is the transpose of the identity 1_{Fc};
the component FGd\xrightarrow {\epsilon _d}d of the counit is the transpose of the identity 1_{Gd};
the transposition of a map Fc\xrightarrow {f} d is the composite c\xrightarrow {\eta _c} GFc\xrightarrow {Gf} Gd;
the transposition of a map c\xrightarrow {g} Gd is the composite Fc\xrightarrow {Fg} FGd\xrightarrow {\epsilon _d} d;

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F: C\leftrightarrows D: G be a pair of opposing functors. Then the following are equivalent specifications of an adjunction:

fr:ul.fr:li: there exists a natural bijection D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd);
there exists a pair of natural transformations 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF and FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D satisfying the triangle identities;

there exists a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D so that the formula for adjoint maps induces an isomorphism (-)^\sharp = C(c, Gd)\xrightarrow {F} D(Fc, FGd)\xrightarrow {(\epsilon _d)_*} D(Fc, d).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first implies the second via the triangle identities of the unit and counit.

fr:ul.fr:li: H\eta = \eta 'H, where \eta and \eta ' are the units of the adjunctions;
K\epsilon = \epsilon 'K, where \epsilon and \epsilon ' are the counits of the adjunctions;
transposition commutes with H and K.

fr:title.text: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the forwards direction, suppose that the isomorphisms are natural, and further that the left-hand square commutes; the case in which the right-hand square commutes is similar. By the naturality of the isomorphism in C, the transpose of kf^\sharp is (Gk) f^\flat , while by naturality in D, the transpose of (Fh)g^\sharp is hg^\flat . Since the maps are equal, their transposes must also be equal; this is commutativity of the square on the right.

fr:title.text: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F and F' be left adjoints to G. Then there is a unique natural isomorphism \theta : F\cong F' commuting with the units and counits of the adjunctions.
Dually, right adjoints are also unique up to unique isomorphism commuting with the units and counits.
To show uniqueness, note that \theta _c is uniquely specified as the transpose of \eta '_c across the adjunction F\dashv G, but this relationship is required for commutativity with the units to hold.
There are composite bijections of hom-sets E(F'Fc, e)\cong D(Fc, G'E)\cong C(c, GG'e).

Let \eta and \epsilon be the unit and counits of the adjunction F\dashv G. We give a unit \eta ' and counit \epsilon ' witnessing the adjunction F_*\dashv G_*. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {H} C, the component H\xrightarrow {\eta '_H} GFH is the whiskered natural transformation \eta H. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {K} D, the component FGK\xrightarrow {\epsilon '_K} K is similarly \epsilon K.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor so that, for each object d\in D, there exists a cofree object Gd\in C, i.e. an object Gd\in C together with an isomorphism {D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd)} natural in D. Then there exists a unique extension of this assignment into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C, which is then necessarily right adjoint to F.
Dually, suppose that for each d\in D, there exists a free object Fd\in C. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C which is necessarily left adjoint to F.

fr:title.text: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:title.text: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Right adjoints preserve limits. Dually, left adjoints preserve colimits.

Letting \Delta be the constant diagram functor, we have the following series of natural isomorphisms: \begin {aligned} C^J(\Delta c, GK) &\cong D^J(F\Delta c, K) &&\text {by (1)}\\\\ &\cong D^J(\Delta Fc, K) &&\text {by (2)}\\\\ &\cong D(Fc, \operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the definition of limits}\\\\ &\cong C(c, G\operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the adjunction}. \end {aligned} By definition of limits, this exhibits G\operatorname *{lim}_J K as a limit of GK.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with locally small complete domain D. Suppose that D satisfies the solution set condition: for each object c in C, there exists a small family of maps c\xrightarrow {f_i} Gd_i in C such that any map c\xrightarrow {f} Gd factors through one of the f_i via the G-image of a map d_i\to d in D. Then G admits a left adjoint.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with complete domain and locally small domain and codomain. Suppose that D has a small coseparating family and that every collection of subobjects x_\alpha \hookrightarrow x in D admits a meet, i.e. a limit. Then G has a left adjoint.
Let C and D be categories. The functor category D^C has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, functors C\to D;
as morphisms, natural transformations;
as composition, vertical composition;
as identities, the identity natural transformations.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A natural transformation F\xrightarrow {\alpha } G between functors C\xrightarrow {F,G} D consists of, for every object x\in C, a morphism \alpha _x: Fx\to Gx (the components) such that, for every morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y in C, the following diagram commutes:
A morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y in a category is an isomorphism if there exists an inverse morphism y\xrightarrow {f^{-1}}x such that f^{-1}f = 1_x and ff^{-1} = 1_y, i.e.
and
commute. If there exists an isomorphism between x and y, we say they are isomorphic and write x\cong y.
